column1: alert("Permission must be sought to use images or text.\nThank you")

arrDescriptions[0]="Antenna
Insects use their antennae to learn about their environment. They detect smells, tastes and air movement"

arrDescriptions[1]="Brain
Although it is small it allows the bee to navigate large areas and to communicate through dance"

arrDescriptions[2]="Mandible
These 'jaws' are used to manipulate pollen and to defend the honeybee colony from invaders"

arrDescriptions[4]="Hypopharyngeal glands
These produce secretions which can feed larval bees and convert nectar into honey"

arrDescriptions[5]="Salivary glands
The saliva is mixed with bees wax to make it sticky"

arrDescriptions[6]="Flight muscle
They can contract several times with one single nerve impulse, allowing the wings to beat faster"

arrDescriptions[7]="Crop (honey stomach)
The bee stores nectar here which it can pass on to other bees in the colony"

arrDescriptions[8]="Malpighian tubules:
These are the honeybee's kidneys. They remove waste from the bees food"

arrDescriptions[9]="Mid gut
This is bee's true stomach"

arrDescriptions[10]="Rectum
This is very expandable meaning the bee can go the whole winter without going to the toilet"

arrDescriptions[13]="Hind leg
This leg has a special 'pollen basket' which the bee packs pollen into to take home to the colony"

arrDescriptions[15]="Fore leg
This leg has a special structure which the bee uses to clean its antennae if they get clogged with pollen"

arrDescriptions[16]="Tongue
Honeybee tongues have to be long and flexible to allow them to drink nectar from flowers"

arrDescriptions[17]="Venom sac and sting
The venom sac contains a cocktail of chemicals which the bee injects using a modified egg-laying tube"

arrDescriptions[18]="Wax glands
Honeycombs are made from a special wax which the bee produces from several glands along its underbelly"
Move the cursor around to reveal what each part of the bee does
